posts.name: Brayden DeGraff
posts.cooked: Hi, I was configuring the new radio for 2025. I updated the firmware and completed the setup, including flipping the switch on the back. However, when I try to connect, the WiFi doesn’t show up on the computer. But when I tether it via Ethernet, it connects.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I am unsure of the full details, but I believe I saw somewhere that these new radios have two different frequency settings and you have to either adjust the radio or your computer to pick up the signals.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
I don’t have first hand experience with the radios, but I’ve come across a few threads, hopefully they’ll help

2xVH-109 stopped working Control System

link_counts.title: Robot radio not transmitting WIFI! Can't connect to robot

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The new radio runs on the 6 GhZ band.  If your computer doesn’t support that band, you won’t be able to find the network.

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked: To use 6ghz mode, you need a laptop with Wifi 6. Unlikely you have that, so you need a second radio to act as a bridge between your laptop and the robot radio. See the docs here.

link_counts.title: Practicing At Home | FIRST FRC Radio

posts.name: Bodi
posts.cooked: We have also had this problem. After asking around we found the consensus was that the ultimate solution is using another radio to create an access point. There docs about how to do this on VividHosting. We don’t have a laptop that supports 6ghz so we are currently power cycling the radio a bunch until it dumb-luck boots into 2.4ghz mode so we can connect.
Can you describe what LED’s are on on the Radio? The 2.4GHZ light should be illuminated solid according to the docs.

link_counts.title: Status Light Quick Reference — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Have you set the mode to Robot radio on the radio.local page?

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: If you only have a single VH-109 you’ll want to configure it as a robot radio and flip dip switch 3 into the on position to enable 2.4GHz. Documentation for this configuration here https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/practicing-at-home#id-2.4ghz-access-point

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Kevin Emery
posts.cooked:
Even if their computer does have Wifi 6 support, the VH-109 cannot serve as an access point (for others to connect to) while on the robot due to FCC restrictions.

To connect wirelessly to the robot, you either have to (1) use 2.4Ghz after flipping the appropriate dipswitch on the back or (2) set up a separate 6Ghz access point powered from the wall (whether that be a VH-109, VH-113, or other 6 Ghz AP), and then connect the computer as well as the robot radio to the access point.
